title: SO & SUCH — Structure • Examples • Explanation
subtitle: Master the difference with clear patterns

sections.heading: SO (meaning: very)
examples: He played the violin so beautifully.
I met so many wonderful people.
sections.explanation: Use 'so' to intensify an adjective, adverb, or quantity. Use so much for uncountable nouns and so many for countable nouns.

sections.heading: SUCH (meaning: very, but used with nouns)
examples: Yesterday was such a beautiful day.
They put on such an amazing performance.
My son is being such a little monster today.
sections.explanation: Use 'such' before a noun. Use a/an only with singular countable nouns.

sections.heading: SO vs SUCH (side-by-side)
examples: I'm so hungry. I have such a big appetite.
I'm so sick. I have such a bad cold.
I took so many great pictures.
sections.explanation: 'So' works with adjectives and amounts. 'Such' works with nouns.

sections.heading: SO / SUCH + THAT (result structure)
examples: I was so tired that I went to bed early.
I was so angry that I couldn't breathe.
There were so many people that I decided to walk.
She's such a nice lady that I baked her cookies.
sections.explanation: Shows one action happens because of the intensity of the first part.
